data.text: Contents
Introduction
Water is essential to health and is one of the six basic nutrients, along with carbohydrates, fats, vitamins, protein and minerals.
Benefits to providing good hydration practices show that it can assist in preventing or treating ailments such as (BDA 2017)
Pressure ulcers    Constipation
Urinary tract infections    Kidney stones
Heart disease    Cognitive impairment
Management of diabetes    Low blood pressure
Dizziness,  confusion  and    Poor oral health
falls
Dehydration can increases mortality and length of stay in hospital if not prevented or treated.

Staff involved in the care of patients should have an awareness of the importance of water and hydration to patient health, and should ensure that the provision of fresh drinking water is a fundamental aspect of care that is built into daily ward routines, as well as an understanding of the importance of monitoring and recording hydration status in at risk patients.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Set out procedures for assessing hydration status and fluid management ensuring a patient's hydration needs are met.
Set out procedures for monitoring fluid balance
Definitions

table_items.text: A term used to describe the balance of the input and output of fluids in the body to allow metabolic processes to function correctly
The term used to describe the processes involved in assessing patients' fluid requirements and delivering those requirements safely.
Term used to describe the observation & recording of a patients fluid input and output and appropriate escalation to Clinicians.
An excess of water in the body
A state in which a relative deficiency of fluid causes adverse effects on function and clinical outcome (NHSE 2015)
The provision of an adequate amount of liquid to bodily tissues

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities

Chief Executive has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, the post holder is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document is available. They will delegate the full implementation of this document to the Medical Director.

Chief Nursing Officer, Directors of Nursing and Medical Director – responsible for ensuring that there are systems and processes in place to communicate this policy in all adult clinical areas. Ensure that medical and nursing staff are aware of their responsibility.

Clinical Directors / Sub Directors / Consultants / Junior Doctors – A treatment plan must be recorded in the healthcare records that gives specific parameters for hydration management. If patients require artificial fluid management the medical plan must identify the route of the fluids and the total amount to be infused as prescribed on the drug chart. For patients who require fluid restriction a plan for this must be documented in the healthcare records. The medical team will have reviewed the patient's ongoing fluid restriction or artificial hydration on their ward rounds. Ensuring that any monitoring out of hours is communicated to the on call medical team.

Deputy Director and Associate Directors of Nursing / Matrons / Lead Nurse / Specialist Nurses – responsible for ensuring that this policy is fully implemented at ward and department level. Ensure that relevant and necessary training is given and received. Inform and support staff to undertake the Hydration eLearning.

Senior Sister / Charge Nurse - To ensure that all patients are assessed on admission and that their hydration needs are communicated at handover. Ensure that the Alert / Communication system is updated and whichever symbols used is in place and that the Nutrition Alert / Management Board is correct. Ensure that the PSA has an agreed time to change jugs at a minimum of twice daily, that a red jug lid is used to identify patients who have fluid monitoring required. Where lapses in correct monitoring of patients occur, staff will be made aware and plans put in place to prevent recurrence
Registered Nursing and Midwifery staff must ensure that:-
Patients who are able to manage fluids have their drinks within reach, for those patients who require assistance staff must be allocated each shift to ensure the fluids are given.
Patients who have swallowing difficulties have their fluids thickened to the specified consistency.
Specific individual information is displayed above the patients' bed and communicated to the PSA / Housekeeper / Hostess whilst maintaining the patients privacy and dignity.
An accurate fluid balance is completed for all patients identified as requiring a fluid balance chart.
Handover includes the fluid balance charts and instructions given for their completion and escalation of concerns.
Bedside and electronic observations are kept up to date.
those patients not on a fluid restriction are offered seven hot drinks per day
In summer or heatwave conditions, awareness of the need to increase the availability of drinking water and encourage patients to drink more is communicated to staff and patients / carers.
Water and fluids are offered at all mealtimes.
Where possible, family and friends are informed about the importance of promoting hydration when they visit and how they can help to encourage oral intake.
There is a plan with the patient how they will manage their fluid restriction / allowances, communicating the plan to nursing, PSA, Housekeeper / Hostess.

Patient Services Assistant (PSA) / Ward Hostess / Housekeeper – to provide fresh water at a minimum of twice daily unless instructed by nursing staff that the patient is nil by mouth or on a fluid allowance. Provide hot drinks six times per day unless otherwise instructed by nursing staff, and be mindful of those patients requiring hydration assistance and alert nursing staff if there are concerns.
Assessment of hydration on admission
Dehydration

5.1.1 Dehydration is defined as an excessive loss of body fluid. It is literally the removal of water from an object, however in physiological terms; it entails a deficiency of fluid within an organism.

5.1.2 There are three main types of dehydration: hypotonic or hyponatremic (primarily a loss of electrolytes, sodium in particular), hypertonic or hypernatremic (primarily a loss of water), and isotonic or isonatremic (equal loss of water and electrolytes).
5.1.3 Manifestation of dehydration
Thirst (although this may be absent in the elderly)
Weight loss
Negative fluid balance
Irritability and restlessness
Diminishing skin turgor
Dry mouth and furrowed tongue
Hypotension
Dizziness
Headache
Delirium
Over hydration

5.2.1  Over hydration, caused by drinking too much fluid, can occur both consciously and unconsciously, or whereby intravenous or other methods of administering fluids are incorrectly prescribed or given. Over drinking can occur when someone drinks too much fluid during exercise, some medications dry the mouth and therefore encourage fluid intake, psychogenic polydipsia is a psychiatric condition which compels sufferers to drink large quantities of water, increased thirst can occur with uncontrolled diabetes. Other causes include medical conditions where water retention can be a problem: liver cirrhosis, kidney problems, heart failure and syndrome of inappropriate anti-diuretic hormone (SIADH) or where patient's artificial feeding regimens and fluids are more than the patients output.
Manifestations of over hydration: Early stages:
Headaches
Nausea and vomiting
Changes in mental state (confusion or disorientation)
5.3.1 If left untreated will cause hyponatremia with severe symptoms:
Muscle weakness, spasms or cramps
Seizures
Unconsciousness
Coma
Difficulty in breathing
Cerebral oedema
5.3.2 For patients with medical conditions like heart failure will also develop oedema.

5.3.3 Assess hydration on admission, through measuring weight, urea and electrolytes, baseline observations and ability to drink independently. A urine assessment should be undertaken, observing for urine colour.
5.3.4 Fluid restriction/allowance must be identified by the medical team and documented in the healthcare records
5.3.5 Assessment of the risks of dehydration due to drug therapies must be monitored. Any patient who is identified as being dehydrated must have a plan for fluid management.
Identification of patient with hydration needs

From a patient safety and communications perspective it is very important to identify those patients with hydration needs, so that their care can be monitored and prevent them from getting the wrong fluid. These needs should be communicated whilst maintaining the patient's privacy and dignity.
Where patients have a hydration need, this should be added to the medical and nursing handover sheet and patient healthcare records.
At Broomfield and Southend red jugs lids are used to identify patients that need assistance with drinking
Fluid balance recording, monitoring and review

Patients should have a daily Fluid Balance chart with comprehensive fluid input/output monitoring commenced if any of the following criteria are met: Actual/potential dehydration (e.g. nil by mouth, diarrhoea, vomiting)
For  hours following emergency admission or post-surgery to give a base line assessment of fluid balance
Commencing IV, or subcutaneous fluids
Patients receiving Enteral / parenteral feeding or requiring thickened fluids
Patients with poor urine output i.e. less than 0.5mls/kg/hr
Patients with wound drains
Patients having activated a NEWS trigger
Fluid restriction (e.g. unstable cardiac failure, liver failure, renal failure)
Doubt over fluid status

For acutely unwell catheterised patients who trigger the NEWS score: if the patient is catheterised, the urine output should be recorded at the same frequency as the clinical observations unless otherwise indicated by the medical team. Therefore a patient on hourly observations should have hourly urine measurements recorded. The NEWS algorithm must be followed.
The patient's weight should be recorded daily for patients where fluid restrictions are in place, where the clinical condition of the patient requires monitoring.

Fluid intake should include all fluid, including fluid foods such as ice-cream, jelly, soups and sauces, food supplements, intravenous and subcutaneous fluids, intravenous medications, enteral and parenteral nutrition. Fluid output must include the output from all drains, vomit, urine (including incontinence pads), blood loss, diarrhoea, stoma output and must be measured in millilitres (scales are available for weighing fluids.) Each bodily loss should be recorded in a different column on the fluid chart.
Reason for stopping fluid balance monitoring must be documented in the patient's healthcare record. A patient can only stop fluid balance monitoring if:
The areas identified in 5.3.1 have been resolved
Integrated Care Pathway – Care Plan for the Last Days of Life has been commenced and no artificial fluids are continued
When in doubt, the ultimate decision for stopping fluid balance rests with the lead clinician for the patient's care.
At shift handover, Nursing/Midwifery staff must ensure that they clearly indicate which patients are having fluid balance measurements and of these which present concern

Nutrition alert and or management board will have the appropriate symbol / code displayed for patients requiring fluid monitoring, thickened or restricted fluids. Patients with hydration needs will be highlighted on the patients on their handover sheet and ensure that this is communicated at shift handover
Fluid balance charts must be reviewed as follows:
Routinely:
By nursing/midwifery staff during handover or immediately following handover and at least four hourly thereafter
By medical staff during individual reviews or on the board or ward round
Immediately:
By nursing/midwifery staff when the early warning score (NEWS) is raised or the patient is of concern. Fluid balance review is a routine part of an ABCDE assessment
Nursing / Midwifery staff must immediately refer to a doctor if upon routine or immediate review any of the following are present:
Concern over fluid status
Evidence of poor oral intake
Evidence of poor urine output - < 0.5mls/kg/hr or if weight unknown less than 30mls/hr for 2 hours
Evidence of excessive urine with unknown cause

Cumulative balance should be calculated and documented four hourly as a minimum or at hourly intervals if low urine output of less than 0.5ml/kg/hr or observation recording is more frequent. Maintenance of accurate ongoing data on the fluid balance chart is ultimately the responsibility of the Named Nurse/Midwife for the shift. If there is any doubt about accuracy of fluid balance measurements then serious consideration should be given to:
Bladder scanning
Bladder catheterisation to record hourly urine output accurately
Central venous pressure monitoring should only be used for critically ill patients where fluid status monitoring is critical.
Fluid balance charts need to balanced for each  hour period.
Review of blood chemistry should be completed daily if there is a suspected fluid imbalance and repeated after treatment.
Reassessment of hydration should be undertaken weekly or if condition changes.
Methods of hydration
Oral fluid intake
Seven beverages to be served daily
Jugs of fresh drinking water will be refilled at a minimum of twice daily.
Appropriate drinking vessels will be supplied for each patient

Patients identified as requiring thickened fluids, the consistency (refer to the Speech and Language Therapy Assessment) must be identified to all staff including the PSA / Housekeeper / Hostess using the Nutrition Alert / Risk Management Board above the patient's bed. These patients are at risk of dehydration and therefore close monitoring is an essential element of their care. Any concerns or lack of clarity, ward staff should re-refer to the Speech and Language Therapist for re-assessment or advice.
Patients will be assisted with drinking where needed
Intravenous fluids

Should be given when patients are dehydrated or to prevent dehydration in acute illnesses, when the oral route is not possible or contraindicated, following assessment by medical or non-medical prescribing practitioners.
To maintain fluid balance in patients placed nil by mouth or fasting prior to procedures
Intravenous fluid requirements to be reviewed by the medical team daily and as part of the ward round
Enteral and Parenteral Feeding
Water can also be delivered by enteral feeding tube and is a safe alternative to sub-cutaneous or intravenous delivery in some patients.
How fluid requirements are to be met in enterally tube fed patients will be decided following discussion with the MDT and documented in the patient's healthcare records.
Subcutaneous fluids

In the event that a patient cannot have oral or intravenous fluids subcutaneous fluids can be considered by the clinical team or those allied healthcare professionals who are able to prescribe preparatory medications after a risk assessment.
Training requirements
No specific training requirements.
Monitoring and audit
Each document must outline the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Nutrition and Hydration Steering Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local MSE nutrition and hydration guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the MSE Nutrition and Hydration and Steering group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranet.
